rsbNotes.title: Isa 13–23
rsbNotes.text: 13:1–23:18 Isaiah prophesies concerning the day of the Lord and what it means for the nations. Babylon and Assyria are treated together in the first oracle (13:1–14:27) because Babylon became the crown jewel of the Assyrian Empire. Assyrian kings had themselves crowned as kings of this renowned city. Babylon was regarded as an epitome of religion and culture, and as such Babylon represents the kingdoms of this world. Peter and John continue to use Babylon as a symbol for ungodly nations (1 Pet. 5:13; Rev. 14:8; 16:19; 17:1–18:24).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 19–20
rsbNotes.text: 19:1–20:6 An oracle of judgment concerning Egypt. In contrast to ch. 20, the language of ch. 19 is symbolic, not historically specific.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 19:1
rsbNotes.text: 19:1 oracle. Prophetic message (13:1 note).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 19:3
rsbNotes.text: 19:3 the idols and the sorcerers. On idolatry and divination, see 2:6, 8; 8:19.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 19:4
rsbNotes.text:
19:4 hard master . . . fierce king. Egypt, too, will be subjugated; perhaps this is an allusion to Pharaoh’s cruelty before the Exodus (Ex. 6:9).

Lord God of hosts. See note 1:9.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 19:5
rsbNotes.text: 19:5 river . . . dry. This spells economic disaster for a country whose life depends on the Nile. God can easily dry up Egypt’s many waters.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 19:6
rsbNotes.text: 19:6 reeds and rushes. Contrast 35:6, 7.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 19:7
rsbNotes.text: 19:7 sown by the Nile. Egypt was the bread-basket of many countries because of the regular flooding of the Nile (Gen. 41:57).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 19:9
rsbNotes.text: 19:9 flax . . . white cotton. God’s judgment against Egypt fell on the important industries of fishing (v. 8) and flax products, for which Egypt was famous.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 19:10
rsbNotes.text: 19:10 pillars. The meaning of this Hebrew word is uncertain. Some believe it is a metaphor for the nobles as the “foundation” of the society in contrast to those “who work for pay.” Others suggest “weavers” of cloth. The point is that all aspects of the society will suffer greatly.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 19:11
rsbNotes.text:
19:11 Zoan. Also known as Tanis, this was a city in the Nile Delta (Num. 13:22; Ps. 78:12, 43) and Egypt’s capital at the time.

foolish. God turns the wisdom of the wise into folly.

counselors . . . stupid counsel. See note 11:2.

son of the wise, a son of ancient kings. This sarcastic remark taunts Egypt’s claim to wisdom (cf. 1 Kin. 4:29–31).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 19:12
rsbNotes.text: 19:12 Where then are your wise men. These words addressed to Pharaoh continue to stand as a polemic against human pride (1 Cor. 1:20).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 19:13
rsbNotes.text:
19:13 princes . . . cornerstones. These include political, economic, and religious leaders.

Memphis. This city in Lower Egypt was its ancient capital.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 19:16
rsbNotes.text: 19:16 the hand. See note 14:26, 27.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 19:18
rsbNotes.text:
19:18 five cities. Not just one but five cities will turn to the Lord.

language of Canaan. This shows how great a change is in view, because anything Canaanite was an abomination to the Egyptians (Gen. 43:32; 46:34).

swear allegiance to the Lord. That is, submit completely to God.

City of Destruction. This probably refers to Heliopolis (“City of the Sun,” see text note). Jewish scribes parodied the name by changing the Hebrew word for “sun” to the almost identical Hebrew word for “destruction.”

rsbNotes.title: Isa 19:20
rsbNotes.text:
19:20 sign . . . witness. The altar (v. 19) signifies their commitment to the Lord (cf. Gen. 12:8; 28:22; Josh. 22:26–29).

savior and defender. God will fill these roles to deliver them from oppressors, as He did for Israel in the days of the judges (Judg. 2:18; 3:9, 15).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 19:22
rsbNotes.text: 19:22 strike . . . heal. Divine discipline will draw the Egyptians to the Lord (30:26; Hos. 6:1; 14:1, 2, 4).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 19:23
rsbNotes.text:
19:23 highway. Building this link between Egypt and Assyria symbolizes the removal of the alienation between them (cf. 11:16 note).

Egypt to Assyria. These two great cultures find unity in a common commitment to the Lord.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 19:24
rsbNotes.text: 19:24 blessing in the midst of the earth. Israel, Egypt, and Assyria will join in the patriarchal promises (Gen. 12:2, 3).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 19:25
rsbNotes.text: 19:25 people . . . work of my hands . . . inheritance. Each will share in full covenant membership, signified by three designations: “people” (cf. 10:24; 40:1 note; Ps. 100:3; Jer. 11:4; Hos. 2:23); “work of my hands” (60:21; Ps. 119:73; 138:8); “inheritance” (cf. Deut. 32:9).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 20:1
rsbNotes.text:
20:1 Sargon. This is Sargon II, king of Assyria from 721 to 705 b.c.

Ashdod. This Philistine city rebelled against Assyria at the encouragement of Shabako, the Nubian king (18:1 note) in 713 b.c. It fell in 711. An inscription mentioning Sargon by name has been unearthed at Ashdod.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 20:2
rsbNotes.text: 20:2 sackcloth . . . barefoot. The Lord ordered Isaiah to be partially clad like a captive going into exile. Sackcloth was a garment for times of mourning (15:3; 22:12; 37:1, 2; 58:5), or else the distinctive prophetic garment (2 Kin. 1:8; Zech. 13:4).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 20:3
rsbNotes.text:
20:3 my servant. The phrase refers to a position of trust and honor before God. Moses was God’s friend and servant (Ex. 14:31; Num. 12:7, 8; Deut. 34:5). Also included among God’s servants were Abraham (Ps. 105:42); Jacob (Ezek. 28:25); Joshua (Josh. 24:29); David (37:35; 2 Sam. 3:18; Ps. 132:10); the Suffering Servant (52:13–53:12); and groups of people, such as the prophets (44:26) and restored Israel (41:8, 9; 43:10; 44:1, 2, 21; 45:4; 48:20). God’s servants may suffer, but they are promised a great heritage as “servants of the Lord” (54:17; 65:8, 9, 13–15; 66:14).

three years. It could designate the time that Isaiah walked about as a sign or the duration before the sign would be realized.

sign and a portent. The prophetic style of life (8:18; cf. Deut. 13:1, 2; Jer. 32:20) pointed out the folly of relying on Egypt, because Egypt, like any nation, was vulnerable.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 20:4
rsbNotes.text: 20:4 king of Assyria. Esarhaddon fulfilled this prophecy in 671 b.c.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 20:6
rsbNotes.text:
20:6 in that day. See note 2:11.

in whom we hoped. Egypt’s fate will persuade the people that no ally can help them escape.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 21:1
rsbNotes.text:
21:1 oracle. See note 13:1.

wilderness of the sea. This is probably a sarcastic parody. Babylon’s southern region on the Persian Gulf, known as “Land of the Sea,” will become a wilderness or as good as a wilderness to anyone looking for salvation from there.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 21:2
rsbNotes.text:
21:2 stern vision. The prophet is overwhelmed by what he sees.

betrays . . . destroys. In the course of waging war.

Elam . . . Media. Elam was a major region of Persia. It was allied with Media in 700 b.c. Perhaps as a part of Assyria’s army (5:26 note) Elam helped to conquer Babylon in 689 b.c., as they certainly did in 539 b.c. (11:11; 13:17 and notes).

the sighing. The indefinite subject could refer to the groan of Babylon under Assyrian domination or to the groan of the nations under Babylonian control. The former is more likely, because Babylon rose to power in 605 b.c.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 21:3–4
rsbNotes.text: 21:3, 4 The expressions in these verses convey great psychological suffering on the prophet’s part (16:9–11; 22:4; cf. Dan. 8:27; 10:16–17). The report of Babylon’s fall may have distressed Isaiah because now no one could rescue Judah from Assyria.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 21:5
rsbNotes.text: 21:5 oil the shield. Prepare for battle.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 21:6
rsbNotes.text: 21:6 watchman. Isaiah is God’s watchman in Judah.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 21:7
rsbNotes.text: 21:7 riders . . . camels. Probably signs of an approaching army.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 21:9
rsbNotes.text: 21:9 fallen is Babylon. Finally, the seductive power of Babylon, her religion (17:7–9; 27:9; 46:1–13), and her culture have come to an end (13:19).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 21:10
rsbNotes.text: 21:10 my threshed and winnowed one. Judah is portrayed as an oppressed people, much like the grain under the threshing sledge (28:27, 28; 41:15, 16; Amos 1:3). See note 40:1.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 21:11
rsbNotes.text:
21:11 oracle. See note 13:1.

Dumah. An oasis in Edom at the intersection of the roads from the Red Sea to Palmyra and from the Persian Gulf to Petra.

Seir. Edom. The Edomites ask the prophet what the future will hold.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 21:12
rsbNotes.text: 21:12 Morning . . . night. The future holds both hope and judgment, specifically, relief from Assyrian domination followed by oppression from Babylon.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 21:13
rsbNotes.text:
21:13 oracle. See note 13:1.

Dedanites. Dedan was an oasis 200 miles south of Dumah (Ezek. 27:20; 38:13).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 21:14
rsbNotes.text: 21:14 Tema. This also was an oasis, located 90 miles north of Dedan (Jer. 25:23). The desert peoples provide food and water for the fugitives from the battle.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 21:16
rsbNotes.text:
21:16 Within a year. Arabia’s glory will be directly affected by what happens in Babylon.

Kedar. Arabia, including Syria; the area inhabited by Bedouin tribes (Jer. 49:28, 29).
